ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned SPSS and epidemiology.
I learned a lot about public health and how to do a case study! I also learned about SPSS.
I learned the basics of epidemiological problem solving using research skills and a little bit of SPSS
Lots of statistical calculations and skills related to public health, lots of public health terms
You learn the basics of SPSS, epidemiological statistics, and policy response. But you don't really go very in depth or learn in a systemic way. I found it hard to retain information.
I learned statistical and evaluative methods used in epidemiology
I learned the basics about the study of Public Health and how to efficiently look at and analyze facts and figures surrounding the field.
We learned about statistics and how to do analysis through SPSS through the lens of public health.

I developed a keen eye for detecting misleading article headlines, first of all. In general, I learned how to really understand what scientific studies are saying. I also gained an overview of the statistical side to public health.
Epidemiological terms, study and test types, how to use SPSS, how to interpret epidemiological data, how to evaluate public health reports.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Prerecorded lecture videos and readings were certainly helpful in providing an introduction to epidemiology. Learning to use SPSS was really easy because everything was given step by step. Breakout rooms allowed me to meet other people in the class.

Marney is amazing! I think some of the case studies were a little repetitive, but fun nonetheless. I very much enjoyed the final project. My only comment would be that I thought the quizzes and p-sets were more rigorous than I was expecting based on class work.
Prof White put a lot of thought and effort into organizing this class in an engaging and productive way and varied each week to keep it really interesting and fresh

Strengths: flexible because its hybrid, flipped classroom format was very helpful and beneficial
Weakness: Very fast paced

Strengths: lots of group work, a range of skills from scientific to mathematical to policy stuff, passionate professor.
Weaknesses: FLIPPED CLASSROOM (prerecorded lectures and then zoom group work during class time).  EVERYTHING is on zoom. If you know yourself to have trouble with zoom, this class is NOT worth it.
Also, do NOT take if you don't have a stats background! They say it's open to anyone, but stats knowledge is actually super important. Don't be fooled.

I really appreciated the behavioral health assignment Professor White gave us at the start of the term. It was cool to have the opportunity to implement a positive behavior change as part of my class grade.
the lecture quizzes were often difficult to answe even after completing the lectures and readings

The Zoom format of this course did not detract from the course at all, it could be considered a strength because it allowed for slight flexibility with regards to a schedule. The asynchronous lectures were also very helpful.

Strengths: pretty chill; people were nice. Content was fun if you're interested in statistics. Weaknesses: it was too chill so no one was really making an effort; there was very little real public health "facts;" instead, they were only examples to illustrate statistics.

Strengths- Professor who prioritizes student wellbeing and goes out of her way to meet her students where they are. Flipped classroom learning style makes for engaging classes. Lack of midterm exam allowed me to focus more on learning the material rather than memorizing it. 
Weaknesses- Weekly quizzes were sometimes strangely worded with unclear answers, but occassionally missing such questions does not lower one's grade by much at all.

This course was kind of a flipped classroom, in which lectures were to be watched outside of class, and class time was used for group work. I liked engaging with my fellow students and all the case studies were very informative. I always felt like the length was just right for class time, and there was always something new to be learned. However, I did find the fully virtual setting difficult at points for engagement.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I dont think this course will be offered again but it was incredibly helpful for anyone considering going into public health or who would like to better understand epidemiological studies.
Yes! Great way to get a methods credit.
Yes
Yes, it was a good learning experience
ONLY if you are ok with zoom and good at working independently and in groups and have stats/excel background.
yes. professor white is a pleasure to have and you learn a ton.
If this student would like to take a class to learn about Public Health or simply how to efficiently analyze data as it relates to this field, I would recommend this course.

No, don't take it. The professor is nice and I think she really wants to make the class less stressful, but she overshoots. All group assignments are graded based on completion, so you can tell that none of your groupmates care. And it is not a gut class - you need to do well on the PSETs and the final (~take-home exam format). You don't really learn facts about public health; all you get is statistics about how to calculate risk ratio, etc.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. Marney White was an amazing professor who truly prioritized my and her other students' wellbeing. Relaxed teaching style made for engaging and not intimidating classes.

If you can hold yourself accountable to watch online lectures and engage with zoom classes, this course is awesome. Marney is a fantastic teacher and so sweet, so enthusiastic about the material. I always felt like the cases were relevant, applicable, and interesting. It provided a strong foundation for future studies.
